characters: DO ALL THE GOOD YOU CAN,
T.R. VELIE, JR. UNDERTAKER AND VETERINARY
AS LONG AS EVER YOU CAN.
AT ALL THE TIMES YOU CAN,
IN ALL THE WAYS YOU CAN,
BY ALL THE MEANS YOU CAN,
TO ALL THE PEOPLE YOU CAN,

dialogues.speaker: DOC VELIE
dialogues.text: assayer and notary public, mortician to the citizens of B Rock who have departed to a better place, and veterinaria to its lesser animals. An elderly, somewhat untidy gentle he sits nonchalantly on a chair outside the Bar & Gri Idling with him are three or four other loafers, among th Sam, the middle-aged proprietor of the restaurant. Doc gl casually at his watch; no one else moves. The hot wind  continues listlessly down the empty street.

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall, attractive girl of twenty in dungarees and cotton shirt. She stands just outside the open barn-like door of the garage, staring, from the compulsive force of habit, the endlessly receding tracks. The sultry wind, its gusti slightly increased, blows through her fine dark hair.

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: two enormous men. HECTOR is tall, and there is about him nasty, raw-boned tautness; COLEY is more the anthropoid t long thick arms and a round, iron casing of a belly. They glance down the street, watching incuriously a dust devil swirling in the wind. Now the CAMERA has completed its probe of the town and it denizens. MAIN TITLE and CREDITS are completed...

dialogues.speaker: MR. HASTINGS
dialogues.text: still spineless in his chair, the chair still tilted agai the shack. From o.s. and far away, we hear the horn of th streamliner -- two long "WONKS", a short and a long (engi whistle signal for approach to bridge crossing). Hastings straightens up ever so slightly as he reacts to the oncom train.

dialogues.speaker: STREAMLINER
dialogues.text: moving at tremendous speed.

dialogues.speaker: BRIDGE
dialogues.text: with train barrelling toward it. The horn BLASTS -- three short WONKS (engine whistle signal for stopping at next  station).

dialogues.speaker: HASTINGS
dialogues.text: getting jerkily to his feet, as though charged by a galva current. The uncharacteristic speed of his movements thro the tilted chair to the station platform. He raises an ar to shield his watery eyes from the sun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost inaudible, as  if to himself) Stopping...?

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: heading toward CAMERA, churning across the desert like a  juggernaut. It PANS past CAMERA in a blur of speed. CAMER SWINGS UP on a level with the great iron wheels as the br are applied. The wheels shriek agonizingly against the ra kicking up cinders and a wild flurry of dust. She cuts sp brakes hissing, and starts to slow down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHOOTING from rear of town, toward the railroad tracks. T townspeople step out, frowning, cautious, disturbed. The  secure ritual of the train passing through, never stoppin has somehow, for some unknown reason, been violated.

dialogues.speaker: DOC VELIE
dialogues.text: as his mouth tightens. His air of placidity vanishes, lea his features disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ BROOKS
dialogues.text: Her fine young face stiffens almost imperceptibly. Her ey are coated with a vague emptiness. She seems confused as halfturns toward the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT SHE SEES
dialogues.text: Coley Trimble and Hector David, standing on the porch of hotel. They seem tense, responding variously to what migh be fear. Coley's nostrils flare, his flat ugly mouth  compresses. He looks profoundly serious. Hector wipes a g of dusty sweat from the socket of an eye and blinks rapid

dialogues.speaker: HASTINGS
dialogues.text: as he stands in surprise, nervously alert, watching the t as it comes to a complete stop. His jaw droops with the  slackness of fear.

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with the train stationary before it. A sleek steel door o pullman clangs open. A colored porter carrying a suitcase walks down the wrought-iron steps. He is stately, gray-ha and lean, with the almost finical tidiness travelers asso with trainmen. The man behind him is big-shouldered, a gr like wedge of a man with calm, piercing eyes. There is ab him an air of monumental dependability and quiet humor, b his eyes are those of a man who has lately lived in sombe familiarity with pain. His left arm hangs from his should with that lifeless rigidity of paralysis, while the hand hidden in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY AND PORTER
dialogues.text: The porter puts the suitcase on the platform. In the dist the town and its people are seen staring silently,  motionlessly. The big man glances toward them. He smiles sad, distasteful greeting to the town, its wretched dust. its mean, modest buildings. The porter disappears into th train as the conductor enters scene. He turns slowly,  following Macreedy's gaze...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, staring at  the towns people) Man. They look woebegone and far  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) I'll only be here twenty-four hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a place like this, it could be a  lifetime. (turning to face  Macreedy) Good luck, Mr. Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy nods his thanks. The conductor signals the engin (o.s.) and steps on the train. The diesel's claxon blasts the torrid air ominously. The train slowly, smoothly, beg to move, picking up speed. The cars slip past until, quit suddenly, the Streamliner is gone. For a moment Macreedy  watches it. Then, quite unconsciously, he takes a package cigarettes from his left hand pocket, taps the last one f of the pack, sticks it between his lips and, crumpling th empty pack, drops it beside the tracks. He takes a cardbo book of matches, flicks it open, bends a match in half wi agile fingers, and with a sure frictional motion scrapes head against the sandpaper guard. The match flares, the  cigarette is lit. Macreedy inhales, exhales deeply, and t to pick up his suitcase. Then he sees Hastings, who walks slowly, almost painfully, to him. His Adam's apple grappl protestingly with his collar. After a moment he controls sufficiently to talk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You for Black Rock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily) That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uneasily) There must be some mistake. I'm  Hastings, the telegraph agent. Nobody  told me the train was stopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a ghost of a  grin) They didn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upset) I just said they didn't, and they  ought to. What I -- want to know,  why didn't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Probably didn't think it was  important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Important?! It's the first time the  streamliner stopped here in four  years. (swallowing nervously) You being met? You visiting folks or  something? I mean, whatd'ya want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go to Adobe Flat. Any cabs  available?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if he hadn't heard  right; as if he wanted  everyone in town to  know) Adobe Flat?! (he gulps, recovers  slightly) No cabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the hotel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hastings looks at him blankly. The thousand-yard stare of hypnotic glazes his features.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently) I asked where's the hotel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hastings points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With his suitcase, he cuts across a weedy path, running i Black Rock's single street. For a moment, Hastings stares after him; then he breaks hurriedly, entering telegraph  agent's shack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Hastings, fumbling, picks up the phone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mouthpiece) Hello, Pete? Now, listen...

dialogues.speaker: MAIN STREET
dialogues.text: SHOOTING down the street as Macreedy slowly walks toward hotel. Not a person has moved, each eye is glued on the  stranger. The hollow rasp of Macreedy's tread on the wooden platfor of the "pavement" seems shatteringly loud in the envelopi silence...

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: as she follows the man's movement.

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: ON MACREEDY
dialogues.text: as he walks along. He feels the eyes of everyone followin him, glaring at him. He halts, looks around. The townspeo continue to eye him brazenly, yet with an almost animal  incuriosity. He grins and walks on past a cluster of five six RFD mail boxes and a road sign [1], its paint peeling its face punctured by three or four bullets from a drunk' pistol long ago.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: heading toward the hotel. In b.g. is a relatively small f equipment yard compressed between a general store (which  Macreedy has just passed) and the hotel just ahead. In th yard are a few tractors, and among them huddles a tiny of It is empty; the front window is thick with dust. On it,  etched by an anonymous, childish finger, is a skull and  crossbones. Running diagonally across is the printed lege T.J. HATES J.S. Macreedy notes the inscription with a sort of wry bemusem He walks on, reaching the facade of the weather-beaten ho A gust of wind swirls down the street, momentarily engulf Macreedy and the entire area in a sudden eddying whirlpoo As it subsides...

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY
dialogues.text: As he peers through the dust toward the dingy hotel. It h a narrow stoop and outsize bay windows on each side. Macr mounts the hotel steps. At the top of the steps Coley Tri and Hector David watch him silently. Hector is large and  leanly muscular, yet Coley looms over him like a battlesh He is a gross behemoth of a man, with sharp flinty eyes t size of glistening pinpoints and a slack, oversized jaw.  Both men wear modern Western work clothes, but there is o incongruous accessory which Hector affects. Around his th wrist is a watch with a large flat face and an elaboratel tooled leather strap -- a cheap reproduction of one of th expensive Swiss timepieces which, among many distinguishe accomplishments, tells the day of the week, the month of year, the phase of the moon, etc., etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowing up) 'Afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reaction from Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blocking doorway) Anything I can do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You run this hotel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) Then there's nothing you can do for  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brushes past Coley and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Coley) Find Smith!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coley nods and heads down the street. Hector enters the h

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a typical small town hotel, but crummier, with a ti lobby. Macreedy is waiting at the empty desk as Hector st in, flopping his enormous bulk into a nicked and mothy ch He picks up a newspaper, but his eyes remain on Macreedy. Macreedy waits patiently for the absent clerk. For a mome he studies the open registration ledger; his eyes rove fr the ink-splotched blotter up over the desk to one of thos World War II banners, the imitation silk now stained and  faded. It depicts a shrieking eagle rampant, clutching Th Flag in a claw. Under it, the legend:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near it, a tacky placard proclaims:

dialogues.speaker: AS LONG AS EVER YOU CAN.
dialogues.text: Feeling the eyes of Hector on him, Macreedy turns. Hector meets his gaze with bland, insolent interest. Now a young man (his name is PETE) comes out of a small room behind t registration desk and walks up to it. There is a softness about his regular features, a certain indefinable sugarin about his mouth. He seems tight-lipped, for lorn and unea as he faces Macreedy across the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) I'd like a room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All filled up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) Got any idea where I might --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffly, shaking his  head) This is 1945, mister. There's been a  war on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy looks at the young man with impeccable tolerance Without shifting his gaze, he slowly lets fall his small  suitcase. It thuds softly on the frayed carpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it ended a couple of months  ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but the O.P.A. lingers on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy looks down at the open ledger on the desk before him. The clerk reaches out to close it. Gently, yet firml Macreedy stops him, reopening the big book. He studies it finger straying unconsciously inside his collar. He [...] it to relieve the starchy stiffness. Pete begins to fidget...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know about the O.P.A...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, for establishments with less'n  fifty rooms hotel keepers got to  report regularly about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice fades desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...about tenants and... and...  registration... (drawing himself up) There are penalties imposed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again his voice trails off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes still on the  ledger) You seem to have lots of vacancies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortable) Well... as I said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy leans over the counter to a rack of keys. He run his splayed fingers over the key rack as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of vacancies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're everyone of 'em locked up.  Some are show rooms...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with touching  sincerity) ...for cattle buyers, feed salesmen.  The others -- they're spoken for,  rented to cowboys, ranch hands... (Macreedy listens  respectfully) They pay by the month. For when they  come into town. We provide for their  every wish and comfort. (weakly) You understand...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. But while I'm pondering  it, get a room ready. Just for  tonight. (picking key from  rack at random) This one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete opens his mouth but no sound comes out. [...] at Hec

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: glowering at Pete.

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY AND PETE
dialogues.text: as Macreedy signs the ledger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (signing) Sure could use a bath. Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Head of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy nods, reaches for the bag at his feet. Then he  hesitates, looks at Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know just why you're  interested -- but the name's Macreedy.  I'm... (grins) It's all in the ledger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly, his eyes  glued to Macreedy's  stiff arm) You look like you need a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy says nothing. The wales along his face harden. H picks up his bag and climbs the stairs. As he disappears, Hector lumbers to the desk and grabs the ledger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading aloud) John J. Macreedy. From Los Angeles. (looking up) I wanna know everything he does,  Pete. Check every call -- any mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) And in the meantime...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning harshly) In the meantime, I'll crowd him a  little... (looking up the stairs) ...see if he's got any iron in his  blood...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Pete bites his lower lip thoughtfully,

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in a new bathrobe, before a cracked, discolored mirror. H draws a safety razor down his face, completing his shave; then he wipes a hand over the mirror, which clouds with s almost as fast as he can clear it. o.s., the SOUND of bat water gurgling down the tub drain. He runs a tentative fi inside the collar of his robe, pulling loose a price tag. drops it carefully into a wastebasket. He turns on the fa at the sink to rinse his shaving brush. The rusty pipes c and rumble, roaring as a trickle of water arrives while t drain sucks loudly at its departure. He dries the razor,  turns off the faucet and exits.

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY
dialogues.text: As he walks down the dark, narrow hall. He wears the bath and slippers; a large towel is draped over his head, like prize fighter. He stops outside a door, pushes the towel  from his head to his neck and puts his hand on the knob. is about to insert the key when he tenses. Slowly, silent he turns the knob and throws open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to the door, in the corner of the small, sparsely  furnished room is Macreedy's suitcase, open, its contents askew and scattered over the dusty floor. On the bed spra Hector David, his gigantic body straining the springs. He lies on his back, hands clasped easily under his head, th legs crossed, his Stetson tilted over his low forehead. H is completely unconcerned by Macreedy's entrance. For a m Macreedy stares at him. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly amused) I think you have the wrong room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not budging) You think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, his eyes still on Macreedy, Hector takes off his  elaborate wrist watch and slides it gently into his pants pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else you got on your mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy pauses and takes in the situation. He refuses to baited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you had a mind, boy, you'd of  heard what Pete downstairs said. He  said these here rooms are for us  cowboys. For our every wish and  comfort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this, I guess, is yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I'm in town. And I'm in town,  as any fool can see. You see that,  don't you, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I do. Would you mind very  much if I sort of... (he gestures toward  his suitcase and  clothing) ...clean up this mess and get another  room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. But if you want this  room real bad... (he raises his enormous  bulk to a sitting  position, rubbing  the knuckles of one  big fist with the  palm of his other  hand) ...we could maybe settle your claim  without all this talk. (no answer from  Macreedy) If a man don't claim what's rightfully  his'n, he's nuthin'. What do you  think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guess so. But still you ain't  claimin' this room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all the time guessin', boy.  Don't you ever know anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing I know. Since I got off  the train, I've been needled. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat, slowly) I guess I don't rightly know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment their eyes lock. Then Macreedy goes to his  suitcase and throws his clothes in it. As he goes out the door...

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit around, each with his own thoughts. They are  generally stolid; only Sam seems nervous. He looks up eag as Doc Velie enters the lobby. As he joins Sam... Sam walks light for a big man, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straight) Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) You know who! (Doc grins impishly;  Sam's anger subsides) What do you think, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why ask me? He's no salesman, that's  sure. (again the impish  grin) Unless he's peddling dynamite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squirming visibly) Maybe he's a cop, or something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever see a cop with a stiff arm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squinting thoughtfully) Maybe his arm's all right. Maybe  he's just holding tight to something  in his pocket...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scoffing) Like what? A pistol? A stick of T-N- T? (gleefully) To blow up this whole mangy, miserable  town! (with sudden, almost  naive, seriousness) Why are you so interested, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who, me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, if I was that interested... (his eyes look up  toward the hotel  stairs o.s.) ...I'd ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam follows Doc's gaze...

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE 35X1
dialogues.text: Macreedy walks down the stairs. Pete looks up from the de He is about to dart behind the partition when...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Hold it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks to the desk, smiling at Pete. In b.g., Doc, Sam the loafers watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any cigarettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete studies him, then bends under the counter, coming up with a pack. Doc leaves Sam and is slowly walking toward stranger, eyeing him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy throws the money on the desk and opens the pack, dexterously using the fingers of his left hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long you staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my new room, you mean? (flatly) I'm staying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, in the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just about twenty-four hours. (sharply) Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered) I... I was just askin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evenly) Why? You expecting a convention?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doggedly) I was just askin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy looks at him, inhales deeply on his cigarette th as he slowly lets the smoke out, removes the cigarette an looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Doc is at the desk not far from Macreedy. Macreedy st out, then turns to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where can I rent a car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy smiles and sighs tiredly. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as to a child) Let's put it this way -- if I had a  car and if I wanted to put gas in  it, where would I go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (refusing to cooperate) But you don't have a car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Macreedy) You might try the garage at the end  of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy pauses, looking at Doc, who blandly returns his  stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc nods. Macreedy smiles and walks toward the door; Pete Doc et al watching him. He goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Macreedy walks down hotel steps, a station wagon pulls just before him. Tied with a rope to the right front fend is a magnificent eight-point buck. A stain of dry blood w an uneven course down his glossy flank from an unmistakab bullet hole in his shoulder. Two men get out of the car; of them is Coley Trimble. He sees Macreedy coming toward  him. He stands motionless in the center of the narrow  pavement, picking at his nose with the detachment of a ch The other man is broad and excessively masculine as he sw out from behind the wheel. He walks around the car, joini Coley at the curb. Macreedy comes on. The man with Coley  looks at the stranger with colossal indifference, as  expressionless as the soil of Black Rock. His handsome fa under a dusty hunting cap, is taut and hard and wind-shav Next to Coley he stands motionless, except for the wisp o smoke from a black Cuban cigarette between his thin lips. b.g., the loafers who had been ensconced in the hotel lob move out the door and stand on the porch. They watch Macr Coley and Reno Smith, the handsome, taut-faced man. Silen soems to settle over everything. It is Macreedy who break it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning wearily at  Coley) Here we go again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gently he walks around Coley and Reno Smith and continues down the street. Coley's eyes follow him. Smith goes up t steps of the hotel and enters the lobby. Coley quickly fo him. The loafers on the porch go back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The loafers resume their familiar places as Smith walks  briskly to the clerk's desk. Pete, in anticipation, opens the hotel register, places it before Smith

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deferentially,  gesturing toward the  open register) That's all I know about him, Mr.  Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith doesn't answer; he looks up thoughtfully. His eyes  harden almost imperceptibly as he sees Coley, across the  narrow room, looking out the window after Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Coley's back) Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spinning to face him) I was only...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coley sits in the nearest chair. Beyond Smith, still rest easily against the high counter of Pete's desk, the gigan figure of Hector appears at the top of the stairs. He com down and joins Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Pretty cool guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't push easy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning) That's it -- that's just it. He pushes  too easy. Maybe we oughtta...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hesitates as Doc Velie sidles amiably into earshot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. (archly) I was just wondering what all you  people were worrying about. (Smith looks at him  coldly) Not that I have the slightest idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wonder too much, and you talk  too much. (pauses) It's a bad parlay, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hold no truck with silence. (impishly) I got nothing to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly towering  over Doc) What're you tryin' to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, man. It's just, you worry  about the stranger only if you look  at him... (slowly) ...from a certain aspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you look at him, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (firmly) With the innocence of a fresh-laid  egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Keep it up, Doc. Be funny. Make bad  jokes. (he starts to walk  toward the window,  Doc and Hector  following him) And some day I'll have Coley wash  out your mouth with lye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith looks thoughtfully out the window.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT HE SEES
dialogues.text: Macreedy, down the end of the block, saunters easily up t Liz's garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garage, without a door, opens on the street. Against front of the building is parked a battered bicycle. On on of the barnlike walls a boy of nine is drawing laboriousl with a piece of chalk. He puts the last flourish to a sku and crossbones identical with that seen earlier on the wi of the equipment yard office. Macreedy stops a few feet f him, waiting until the boy prints "T.J.". As he steps bac to admire his handiwork...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, T.J.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T.J. nods. He approaches the wall, raising his chalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This your garage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) Where's the man it belongs to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses. As Macreedy opens his mouth to interrogate  further...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady runs this garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again a pause. T.J. has just completed the final letter o the word "HATES". And again as Macreedy opens his mouth..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd she go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) I dunno. Somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When will she be back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. Sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again the pause. T.J. steps back, having completed his wo which, of course, broadcasts the fact that "T.J. HATES J. And again as Macreedy begins to speak...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In about ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a grin) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: T.J. turns, pulls the bike away from the building, comple a fastidious "pony express" and peddles furiously out of  scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Macreedy, after a moment's hesitation, starts down it. From the far end, at the telegraph agent's shack, a figur starts running toward Macreedy. It is Hastings. INTERCUT  between the two men. Hastings, in his concentration, does see the stranger until he is almost upon him. He slows do suddenly, awkwardly, to a self-conscious walk. Macreedy g at him, passes on, shaking his head speculatively. Hastin with a parting glance, gallops up the hotel steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith, Coley, Hector, Pete, Doc, Sam et al are still in  evidence. Smith is in a tight little group at the desk wi Coley, Hector and Pete. Doc has taken a position at the  window, looking out. Hastings bursts in and half-runs to  Smith...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the excited telegraph agent speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called the Circle T. He ain't got  business there -- not if they don't  know him. Right, Mr. Smith?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith ignores him, thinking. Hastings breathes heavily.  Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hastings) Send a wire to Nick Gandi in Los  Angeles. Tell him to find out all he  can about John J. Macreedy. Tell him  I want to know fast. Sign my name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hastings nods, scribbling on a pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick Gandi. G-A-N-D-I. Care of the  Blake Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hastings nods and hurriedly exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Who's Gandi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith looks at Coley, trying to decide if the question in any way challenges his authority. He concludes not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a private detective. (beat) I drive to L.A. now and then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly worried) He'll get us the dope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll get us anything, for twenty  bucks a day and expenses. (Hector frowns) Hector, you worry too fast and too  easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just, I don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he's just passing through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bet on it. He can only mean  trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles faintly) Hector, you're jumpy as a stall horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doggedly) We oughtta see him... talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) About what? (Hector doesn't answer) What'll we talk to him about? The  birds, the bees? The weather? The  crops? (pauses) You tried -- where'd it get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncomfortably) I only thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. You only thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do? You wait. Like Pete  here. Right, Pete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete nods, his brow furrowed uncomfortably in a frown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all you do. But while you  wait... I talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point the brittle silence is cracked by...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith and those around him look off in the direction of D

dialogues.speaker: DOC VELIE
dialogues.text: peering out. He turns in the direction of Smith and the  others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what do you know? (beaming) Mr. Macreedy seems to be heading for  the jail. (impishly) Now what do you suppose he'd want to  see the Sheriff about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith goes to the window, edging Doc to one side with a  shoulder. He looks out grimly.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT HE SEES
dialogues.text: Macreedy, down the street, cuts up the steps of the jail.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Smith staring out the window with a frown. Doc watching h out of the corner of his eye, a bemused expression crossi his puckish features.

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE on Macreedy as he enters the jail. It is small and  dirty, with only a tired desk, two chairs and the usual p posters on the wall. One side leads to the cell block and Macreedy heads for it. ANGLE from interior of cell block comprising two cells, b of which are open. A man is asleep in the lower bunk of t front cell. The keys are in the lock. Macreedy shakes his head and starts to close the creaking cell door. Sheriff HORN, the man in the bunk, lifts his head, blinking his b eyes. He is in terrible shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it, friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He manages to crawl off the bunk and out toward Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) I ain't hankerin' to get locked in  my own jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I thought you were a guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it happens, I'm the host.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out of the cell, Macreedy following him into the office.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: Tim breaks out a bottle of booze, starts to take a snort, then stops, offers it to Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snort?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't blame you. It's awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a belt that would incapacitate half the county. finishes, smacks his lips, lays the bottle down, and fall into a chair. He looks up at Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly mean) What're you lookin' at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easy) You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat, relaxing) I ain't always this bad -- just that  last night me and my pal Doc Velie,  we did a little celebratin'. At least  I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you celebrating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) You name it. (studies Macreedy) What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Macreedy. I came in on the  Streamliner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim studies him, trying to focus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I came in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) You ain't from around here. Up Tucson  way -- Phoenix? Mesa? You ain't  sellin' cattle nor seed nor nothin'  like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (sighs, then distinctly  as to a child) All I want from you is a little  information. I've got to get to a  place called Adobe Flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reacts; then, tight- lipped) This ain't no information bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy starts to say something, then stops. Reconsideri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing about Black Rock --  everybody's polite. Makes for gracious  living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody asked you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know? (he moves toward the  door, with a rueful  grin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting after him) What about Adobe Flat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a man named Komako.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff reaches for his bottle. In his haste he drops it. Macreedy's hand moves quickly, catching the bottle be it hits the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost a disaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sinking back in his  chair) A fate worse'n death. (he takes the bottle  from Macreedy) You move fast for a crip... for a  big man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment heavy silence. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Komako?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) If there's no further questions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy grins harshly and exits. Tim watches him go, the slowly reaches for the bottle. He pauses, looks at his sh hand. Then he withdraws it and just sits in the chair sta blindly ahead, seeing nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frowning, deep in thought, Macreedy walks down the dusty  street. As he reaches the hotel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Mr. Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy stops, looks toward Smith as he walks out to mee him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the friendliest word I've  heard since I got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Smith joins him, he walks on. Smith falls in step besi him. GO WITH THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins boyishly) My name is Smith. I own the Triple- Bar ranch. (holds out his hand;  Macreedy shakes it) I want to apologize for some of the  folks in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They act like they're sitting on a  keg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A keg...? Of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe diamonds. Maybe  gunpowder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disarmingly) No. Nothing like that. We're a little  suspicious of strangers is all.  Hangover from the old days. The old  West.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought the tradition of the old  West was hospitality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a sincere smile) I'm trying to be hospitable, Mr.  Macreedy. (boyishly pushes his  dusty cap back on  his head) Going to be around for a while?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you like to go hunting  tomorrow? I'd be proud to have you  as my guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, but I'm afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with admirable candor) You mean, because of your arm? (slaps Macreedy's  shoulder in a  friendly,  understanding gesture) I knew a man once, lost an arm in a  threshing accident. Used to hunt all  the time. (almost too blandly) But he was quite a man. He... (pauses; then, with  discreet and charming  gravity) I'm sorry. I... What I mean is -- if  there's anything I can do while you're  around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for... (sighs) Never mind. Thanks, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) You're looking for what, Mr. Macreedy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyeing him) A man named Komako.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no hesitation) Komako -- Sure, I remember him --  Japanese farmer. Never had a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got here in '41 -- just before  Pearl Harbor. Three months later he  was shipped to one of those relocation  centers. (shaking his head) Tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one did he go to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think maybe if I wrote him, the  letter would be forwarded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it would. Write your letter.  I'll see it gets out tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't be too much trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny. Because I think it would be a  great deal of trouble for you. It's  been a great deal of trouble for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point they are in front of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy stops, as does Smith. He looks keenly at Smith a he takes from his inner jacket pocket a half-dozen letter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrote these letters to Komako.  They weren't forwarded. They were  returned -- address unknown. (he smiles grimly at  Smith) So I guess there's nothing you can  do for me, after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith opens his mouth to reply when the NOISE of a jeep o interrupts him. The jeep comes INTO SHOT. Liz Brooks, at wheel, cuts the engine and jumps out. Smith ambles silent to a wall and leans against it. Liz reaches behind the  driver's seat and hoists, with both hands and some effort five-gallon drum of axle grease from the floor of the jee As she rests it on the rear fender...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going to her) Need a little help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl looks at Smith, who has made no attempt to help  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can manage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lifts the drum to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I need a little help. (she looks at him  questioningly) I'd like to rent your jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be two dollars an hour, gas  extra, and ten dollars for my time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Liz) Aren't you going to ask him where he  wants to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz looks from Smith to Macreedy, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to go to Adobe Flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz hesitates. Macreedy notes her confusion as her eyes s Smith's for instructions. Quickly he moves in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road's marked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Yeah. It's about six -- seven miles  down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I won't need your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy hands her a bill. She fumbles with it, not knowi what else to do. Her eyes drift to Macreedy's stiff arm..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uneasily) I thought you might... need a little  help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can manage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps toward the jeep as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz. Do you have a license to rent  cars? You could get into trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. I won't mention it  to the Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps into jeep and, with one hand expertly manipulati the controls, drives off.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH AND LIZ
dialogues.text: Smith turns his attention to the girl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) You shouldn't have done that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it would be better if he  went out there and got done with it. (Smith looks at her  sharply) I mean, what could he find out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment Smith doesn't answer. Instead, with a half f he lifts the bill Macreedy had given her from Liz's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he studies it) This is liable to be the hardest ten  dollars you ever earned in your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crumples it, pokes the wad in her hand and walks off d the street as...

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Tim sits in his chair, still staring sightlessly at the  whiskey bottle. Smith enters. He looks from Tim to the bo on the table, then back to Tim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat,  disinterestedly) What did he want -- the stranger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abstractedly) He asked about Komako. (looking up at Smith) You think he'll kick up a storm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily) A storm? About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. All I know, I don't  want trouble around here. (pauses awkwardly,  then) Never again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trouble? You don't know anything  about Komako, now do you, Tim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not. That's the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point is, what you don't know  can't hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there's something I ought to  know. Maybe I ought to ask you...  before the stranger comes back and  starts breathing down my neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a faint smile) Tim, you're a lost ball in the high  weeds. I told you a long time ago,  nothing happened for you to worry  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stands up, facing  Smith) Thing is, I do worry. Maybe I ain't  much else, but I'm sure a worrier. (beat, then with soft  emphasis) And I'm still the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then do your job, Tim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is my job, Mr. Smith? Maybe I'd  better find out before Macreedy does  it for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evenly) Macreedy'll do nothing, Tim. And  neither will you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose I decide to try?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be dangerous. You got the  body of a hippo, Tim, but the brain  of a rabbit. Don't overtax it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares harshly at the Sheriff. Tim tries unsuccessfull to meet his gaze. Then, slowly, he sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lowering his eyes,  mumbling) Yes, Mr. Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith slowly walks behind Tim's chair and silently,  patronizingly pats the Sheriff's slack shoulder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hastings is sitting at his desk. The telegraph ticker sta to splutter. Hastings rushes to it. He listens, and start to scribble. Then he gulps nervously, a confused expressi on his face. As the telegraph key stops as suddenly as it had begun, Hastings jumps up frantically and, holding the sheet of paper, runs out of the shack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he runs toward hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: with Doc, Sam, Coley, Hector and Pete on the porch. Hasti runs up the steps, pausing momentarily. His jaws move, bu CAMERA is too far away to pick up his obvious question. C gestures toward the jail; then Hastings turns and runs do the steps followed by Doc et al.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hastings runs down the street toward the jail followed by Doc et al.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Hastings runs up the steps with a hobnailed clatter. S comes out to investigate, followed by Tim. Doc, et al are congregated at the foot of the steps. Hastings slaps the  sheet of paper in front of Smith. Utter quiet. Everyone s at Smith, waiting for a reaction -- everyone except Tim, stares straight ahead, seeing nothing, and Doc, whose eye are locked sympathetically on Tim. Smith finishes reading the wire. His face is expressionless. After a moment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Smith) From L.A.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith doesn't answer but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! From that private detective!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Smith) What does he say? Who is this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of him, that's what he  says! He checked and there's no John  J. Macreedy. No listing -- no record --  no information. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, after a  beat, to Smith) Where does that leave us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you where...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He folds the message carefully, puts it in his pocket.  Abruptly Tim turns and disappears inside his office. Smit with some restraint, walks down the steps to the street.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: as he takes Coley's arm, and Pete's. The trio moves away, taking a position perhaps 15 feet from Doc. Hector, Sam a Hastings move toward them.

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In b.g. at a respectful distance are Hector, Sam and Hast SHOOT parallel to tracks, which disappear far into the  horizon. The following dialogue is delivered in an undertone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Coley) Now, Coley...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes a breath, then) I think Macreedy's a nothing. A  nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there's nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there? (a beat) You got brains, you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squirming) But what can he find out? That Komako  was...? (Smith glares at him) Suppose he finds out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nobody like Macreedy can raise a  pretty big stink. The point is...  who would miss a nobody like Macreedy  if he just, say, disappeared? Who,  Coley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coley is terribly preoccupied, balances himself, like a c on a steel rail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Coley!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (galvanized from the  rail) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, maybe he won't find anything.  Maybe he'll just go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Macreedy. I know those maimed  guys. Their minds get twisted. They  put on hair shirts and act like  martyrs. They're all of 'em do- gooders, trouble makers, freaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there's no danger yet. Let's  wait and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting,  appealing to Coley  as an equal) No danger, he says. This guy's like  a carrier of small pox. Since he  arrives, there's been a fever in  this town, an infection. And it's  spreading. (he glances from Coley  to Pete) Hastings has been in a sick sweat,  running around, shooting off his  face. Doc, for the first time in  four years, gets snotty with me.  Liz... (to Pete) ...your own sister -- acts like a  fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hotly) She's just a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scoffing) Kid! She must have strained every  muscle in her head to get so stupid!  Renting him a jeep! And Tim -- Tim,  the rum-dum. Tim suddenly decides  he's gotta act like a Sheriff. (to Coley, gesturing  at Pete) And he says what's the danger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brittle silence for a moment. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily) Of course, if you want to take the  chance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) Not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not all right! You're so mighty  quick to kill -- he's not an animal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Coley, with mock  surprise) Well, listen to little spitfire... (turning slowly on  Pete) You sniveling toad! I'm saving your  neck! If I don't, who will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squirming) All I said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who will?! Doc? Tim? Your sister,  with the rocks in her head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing about your sister -- she's  got twice the guts you have. You're  only fit for running away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too late for that. (belligerently, slowly,  at Pete) He's in this, and he ain't running  no place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long, electric silence. Pete is defeated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) All right, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses for emphasis. Then, as he starts to talk again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim stands facing the wall, shoulders hunched, suffering. Doc comes in and watches him silently, Tim turns, facing  Doc, turns again to concentrate on a faded newspaper  photograph framed and hanging on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: TIM
dialogues.text: SHOOTING over his shoulder. Focal point: the "photograph" It shows a widly grinning, moderately alert and healthy T of perhaps five years ago. He is wearing, proudly, his ba of office, and behind him, mildly interested in the  proceedings, is Reno Smith, his erstwhile sponsor. The he on the photo reads: DEPUTY SHERIFF NAMED FOR BLACK ROCK.

dialogues.speaker: TIM AND DOC
dialogues.text: Tim takes the photo off the wall and, holding it, turns t face Doc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let Smith find himself a new boy. I  can't take it another day. (pauses, looks at Doc) If you're a sheriff, they gotta  respect you, otherwise you can't do  your job. (shakes his head) They just laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't laugh, Tim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it out, Tim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the name of well-adjusted manhood,  snap out of it. You're going to get  a complex or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four years ago if I'd of done my  job... if I'd of checked up and found  out what happened. But I didn't!  Just like Smith figured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What could you have found out? They  told you a story. You had to believe  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc squirms but doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. (ironically) I lead a quiet, contemplative life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, I didn't even try to find out. (a beat) Don't you understand? (he taps the badge on  his chest) When you wear that badge, you're the  Law. And when something happens,  against the Law, you're supposed to  do something about it. It's your  job. (simply) Me... I did nothin'. And that's what's  eatin' me. What kind of prescription  you got for that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I've never been able  to find one for myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim takes off his badge and throws it on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only one thing -- don't quit, Tim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe this feller Macreedy has the  prescription.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other. Slowly Tim picks up his badge an pins it back on.

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old marker, jutting on an angle at the side of the roa reads: ADOBE FLAT. Beneath it an arrow points ahead. Macr steers the jeep up the narrow, rutted trail between a ser of enormous boulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he drives to the far end of the boulders, reaching a f piece of land completely surrounded by rocks. Beyond the  rocks is what remains of a burned-out ranch house, and an abandoned well.

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY
dialogues.text: in the wreckage. The remains of an iron bed. The burned-o shell of a pick-up truck. Part of a stove. A morass of  bottles, all sizes and shapes, some of them broken. Macre halts momentarily beside the well. Reaching out he touche the warped sun-beaten boards that cover the mouth. He rem one, and, picking up a pebble, drops it through the openi There is a long beat and then, from far, far below we HEA faint PLUNK (o.s.). He replaces the board and walks to a  broken wall. He touches the burned out frame of a picture The frame falls to the ground, leaving an un-scorched squ on the surface of the wall. He goes past a solitary stand stone chimney. Suddenly he halts, arrested by something a the rubble, the rottenness and the ashes.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT HE SEES
dialogues.text: Surrounded by the seared and blackened earth is a rectang patch of lovely wild flowers.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MACREEDY
dialogues.text: studying the brightly colored flowers. His face is lined thought. He stoops, gathers a few buds in his hand. He  examines them, his brow furrowed. As he slowly twirls a f between thumb and forefinger, CAMERA PANS from Macreedy i long slow arc, taking in miles and miles of barren wastel CAMERA RISES, TILTING UPWARD to a cliff far away and shie from Macreedy's view by the intervening rocks and ridges.

dialogues.speaker: CLIFF
dialogues.text: and on it the outline of an automobile.

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR
dialogues.text: empty. It is parked on a narrow dirt road. On one side of the road the cliff falls abruptly to the valley far below on the other, the steep, shaly outcropping continues to r For a moment CAMERA HOLDS on the car. Then it PANS SLOWLY upward about fifty feet, HOLDING this time on...

dialogues.speaker: PINNACLE OF CLIFF
dialogues.text: where a man is looking off toward Adobe Flat through a pa of high-powered glasses. The man is Coley Trimble.

dialogues.speaker: ADOBE WELLS
dialogues.text: Grimly he walks toward the jeep, still holding the wild  flowers. Now he pockets them, jumps into the vehicle and  drives off.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLIFF
dialogues.text: continues to train his glasses on Macreedy far below in t moving jeep.

dialogues.speaker: THE JEEP
dialogues.text: driving steadily over rough, rocky terrain.

dialogues.speaker: COLEY
dialogues.text: climbs down from the pinnacle of the cliff and enters a b powerful '36 Packard sedan.

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY
dialogues.text: shifts to low gear as the jeep presses into hilly country

dialogues.speaker: COLEY
dialogues.text: turns on the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY
dialogues.text: as it winds along a road with the cliff rising on one sid and falling off steeply on the other. He rounds a curve,  passes an insignificant side road, drives on.

dialogues.speaker: THE SIDE ROAD
dialogues.text: The car with Coley at the wheel pulls out, follows Macree INTERCUT between the two cars, with the distance between  them constantly diminishing.

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a straightaway, cutting through rocky outcroppings on bot sides. Macreedy's jeep roars by, pursued by the gaining  Packard.

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY IN JEEP
dialogues.text: For the first time he is aware that he is being followed, and that the man at the wheel of the big Packard is Coley

dialogues.speaker: SHOT
dialogues.text: picking up tremendous speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: proceeding over a series of turns, inclines, declivities  (according to location terrain). Engines roar, brakes whi tires scream, skidding on the turns.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD BED
dialogues.text: as Coley overtakes Macreedy. He steers the big car within foot or two of the jeep. The terrain has steepened; on th right there is nothing between the road and the valley fl far below but a few inches of soft shoulder. As Macreedy pulls wide on a razor turn, Coley tries to co inside him. Macreedy, fighting for control of the veering jeep, succeeds in cutting him off.

dialogues.speaker: CURVE IN ROAD
dialogues.text: In the approach, Coley cuts sharp into the jeep. The jeep seems to roll with the blow, then leaps ahead, maneuverin the turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coley is flustered, his face blood-shot with fury. He see to generate an atmosphere of vicious, cruel craziness; th wild smile across his mouth is almost sensual, obscene. H floorboards the Packard. Like some monstrous battering ra the heavy car smashes into the jeep's rear bumper, kickin the smaller vehicle jerkily ahead. Coley floorboards the pedal, again. Each time he slams into the jeep with sicke force, with the brutal abrasion of metal pounding metal.

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY
dialogues.text: With one arm he works frantically to keep his under-sized car on the twisty road. He sees ahead a precipitous cliff falling off on an impossibly sharp curve. He makes a  decision... Just ahead the gradient is comparatively gradual, however steep by normal standards. He swings the jeep off the roa onto the declivity. The car plunges downward, miraculousl upright. Macreedy jockeys it to a whirring, shuddering ha in the soft sand at the bottom of a draw. Macreedy turns slightly and looks up the mountain-side wi the road at its summit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: standing at the edge of the road, peering down at him. In b.g., the Packard. Coley turns emphatically, gets into ca drives off.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO MACREEDY
dialogues.text: His face is caked with the sweat of his exertions and dus kicked up by the grinding wheels. He exhales heavily and  runs a shaky hand across the side of his head. He becomes aware suddenly of a NOISE, a trickling, an unmistakable t as of running water. He frowns, opens the jeep door...

dialogues.speaker: JEEP
dialogues.text: as Macreedy unlatches the hood and throws it open. The NO continues. Macreedy examines the engine and finds the  difficulty...

dialogues.speaker: ENGINE
dialogues.text: focal point: the nut joining the gas line with the carbur has worked loose in the jouncing the car has taken. With hand Macreedy screws it tight.

dialogues.speaker: JEEP
dialogues.text: as Macreedy lowers the hood, re-enters jeep. He turns on  ignition. The engine fires. As he drives slowly out of th ravine...

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: his long face even more horsey than usual, with half an a in his mouth. He stands in front of the grocery store, wi the baskets of fruit on the sidewalk. He looks up, stops  crunching.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: at the window of the Bar & Grill, cleaning an ear wit toothpick. He looks out. The toothpick is motionless.

dialogues.speaker: HASTINGS
dialogues.text: fidgeting outside his shack. He looks up. His Adam's appl turns completely over.

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE
dialogues.text: Macreedy slowly driving the jeep toward Liz's garage. He  looks neither to the right nor left.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING SMITH AND COLEY
dialogues.text: Standing on the porch of the hotel, watching. Smith's fac compresses, and his eyes swivel to rest on Coley's with c contemptuous anger. Coley licks his lips uneasily. Smith  turns and enters the hotel. Coley meekly follows.

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY
dialogues.text: He brakes the jeep before the garage. No one is there. He parks the vehicle, gets out and heads down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy is about to go up the steps when he sees Coley's car at the curb. Both right fenders are creased. An ugly, jagged break has split the front bumper almost in half, o part angling crazily toward the sky, the other drooping i the dust of the road. Smith and Coley come out of the hot They stand on the porch, watching Macreedy as he in turn  watches the car. They exchange a glance. Smith nods, so..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it's not Macreedy - the  world's champion road hog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks down the steps to the street, joining Macreedy.  Smith remains on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's a small world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But such an unfriendly one. Now why  did you want to crowd me off the  road?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a slow grin) I'm kind of sorry if I've incurred  your displeasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look what you did to my car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's anything I can do to make  up for it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to be careful, man -- all  that one-arm driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be glad to pay the damages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a threat to life and limb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fortunately no one was hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could get yourself killed that  way -- nosin' all over the  countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the real danger, I can see  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why that's pretty smart of you. How  long you intend to keep it up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting out of here, right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks up the steps, past Smith, and into the hotel. Co glances up at Smith, grinning with self-satisfaction, lik small boy who has carried out perfectly the instructions his teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lobby empty except for Pete behind the desk. Macreedy goes to him. Pete seems elaborately occupied arranging an re-arranging a few file cards. Smith enters the lobby. He stands in b.g. watching Macreedy and the desk clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Pete) Still expecting that convention?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) What...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're expecting any extra cowboys,  my room is available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're checking out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Is there a train through here tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing till tomorrow morning. The  streamliner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that. How about freights? (Pete shakes his head) Milk train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow. After the streamliner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closest stop is Sand City -- thirty- two miles away. (a beat) You're in such a hurry, you should  have never got off here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm inclined to agree with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns, walks toward porch. Pete looks at Smith. Smith' eyes follow Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the gloom of the lube pit, Liz's mechanic, a dirty old man, is draining the oil out of the crankcase of the car the rack. The girl stands beside the pit, silently watchi the old man. Now she pauses, looks o.s. toward the open g doors...

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY
dialogues.text: entering the scene, stopping to look at Liz's jeep parked front of the wide doors. He turns his eyes vaguely in the direction of Liz, but he doesn't see her in the shadows b the car on the rack, He advances a step, pausing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody home?

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does not answer. Instead, she silently twists the  crankcase petcock, stopping the flow of oil. She watches  Macreedy closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy again shifts his eyes to the jeep, then, with  decision, he goes to a work bench, opening the drawers an rummaging among the contents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) If you're looking for the jeep key...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy turns as Liz comes toward him. She gestures towa the open drawers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it's not there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy waits for her to go on. She doesn't. She stands  there, staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) In that case, where do you suggest I  look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns, walks back toward the lube pit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over her shoulders) The jeep's not for rent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was, just a few hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) Things change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with grim amusement) Sure. And Smith is the kid who changes  'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't answer. Macreedy goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Brooks. (softly) What's the matter with this town of  yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. It's none of your concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why are they all so concerned  about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I concerned?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're not. But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily) But it strikes me you're a little  too unconcerned. So unconcerned you  won't even rent me a jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flaring) I don't run a taxi service. I don't  have a license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish others in this town were as  scrupulously devoted to law and order  as you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hotly) Why don't you lay off! If you don't  like it here, go back where you came  from!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny thing. They try to kill me,  and you feel persecuted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to get involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Involved in what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (retreating) Whatever you're up to. Whatever  happens, I've got to go on living  here. These people are my neighbors,  my friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) This is my town, Mr. Macreedy, like  it or not. Whatever happened here,  it was long ago, now it's... it's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evenly) Dead and buried? (a beat) Whatever did happen, you don't seem  to like it. Why do you stick around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Because of my brother. Pete. He'd  never leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you ever think of going without  him. You're sort of independent and  he's... he's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weak. I know. That's why I couldn't  leave him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) What did your brother do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He... I... (flaring again) What do you care? What do you care  about Black Rock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing much. Only, there're not  many places like this in America --  but even one is too many. Because I  think something sort of bad happened  here. (frowning) Something I can't find the handle  to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just think so. You don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This much I know -- the rule of law  has been suspended in this town. The  gorillas have taken over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fine one to talk! You come  in here, sneaking around, trying to  steal the key to my jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kind of had a notion that was the  only way I could get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens her mouth to answer, but she doesn't know what say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) Was I wrong, Miss Brooks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits as she tries to answer, and again she can't. For moment he watches her struggle in anguished silence with  herself. Then he turns and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: walks thoughtfully down street. He comes abreast of hotel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where Smith is still sitting. For a moment he watches Mac speculatively, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) Mr. Macreedy. (reasonably, as  Macreedy turns toward  him) I'd like to ask you a few questions...  as long as you're around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking up steps) I'm around all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands facing Smith on the porch, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with just a touch of  wryness) You probably know that Miss Brooks  is no longer in the car rental  business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemnly) Good. I wouldn't want to see that  girl get into trouble...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...what with rental permits, gas  rationing... you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. I admire your sturdy sense of  responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissively) It's just, a girl like that has a  future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's talk about my future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost slyly) Do you have the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't seem to be going any place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the other chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) I hear you handle a jeep real well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a way with jeeps. A certain  familiarity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I understand. You're an Army  man. (looking at Macreedy's  stiff arm) Where'd you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Italy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincerely) Tough. I tried to get in myself, the  day after those rats bombed Pearl  Harbor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What stopped you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The physical. They wouldn't take me.  The morning after Pearl, I was the  first man in line at Marine recruiting  in Sand City. And they wouldn't take  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) Tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do in Los Angeles, Mr.  Macreedy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm retired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a pretty young man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might say I was forced into  retirement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you looking for in Adobe  Flat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Komako, like I told you. Like you  told me, he wasn't there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith laughs quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. It's just -- I don't believe  you. I believe a man is as big as  what he seeks. I believe you're a  big man, Mr. Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flattery will get you nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would a man like you be looking  for a lousy Jap farmer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm not so big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
