dialogues.text: Yes, you are. (a beat; looking hard  at Macreedy) I believe that a man is as big as  the things that make him mad. Nobody  around here has been big enough to  make you mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you mad, Mr. Smith?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me...? Nothing in particular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bemused) I see. You're a big man, too. Only... (calmly) ...the Japanese make you mad...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's different. After the sneak  attack on Pearl Harbor... after  Bataan...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and Komako made you mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the same thing. (scoffing) Loyal Japanese-Americans -- that's a  laugh. They're mad dogs. Look at  Corregidor, the death march.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did Komako have to do with  Corregidor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't he a Jap? Look, Macreedy,  there's a law in this county against  shooting dogs. But if I see a mad  dog loose, I don't wait for him to  bite me. (exhales sharply,  shaking his head  with irritation) I swear, you're beginning to make me  mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) All strangers do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not all. Some of 'em. When they come  here snooping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snooping for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, outsiders coming around,  looking for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pressing) For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. People are always  looking for something in this part  of the West. To the historian, it's  the "Old West." To the book writers,  it's the "Wild West." To the  businessmen, it's the "Undeveloped  West." They all say we're backward  and poor, and I guess we are. (snorts) We don't even have enough water. (a beat) But this place, to us, is our West. (heatedly) I just wish they'd leave us alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave you alone to do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coldly) I don't know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to Komako?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He went away, I told you. Shortly  after he left, a bunch of kids got  fooling around out his place. They  burned it down. It was one of those  things -- you know how kids are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy laughs quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Only -- I don't believe  you. Any more than I believed you  about the letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) You don't seem to believe anything I  say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely) Yes, I do -- about businessmen, for  instance. I think a businessman would  be interested in Adobe Flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that land lying fallow. Could be  put to some use. Like a graveyard. (Smith opens his mouth  to speak but Macreedy  goes on) A historian might be interested,  too. Because of the strange customs  around here, such as burying cattle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burying cattle...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Something's buried out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the wild flowers from his pocket, holding them i front of Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See these wild flowers? That means a  grave. I've seen it overseas. I figure  it isn't a man's grave or someone  would have marked it. Sort of a  mystery, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort of. Maybe you can figure it  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy gets up, half turns to Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts down the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not give it a whirl? (Macreedy turns) It'll help you pass the time... (continued;  meaningfully) ...for a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not interested. I got other things  to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and walks down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: headed towards Doc's establishment. The building, which s Doc as home, office and laboratory, has centered on a pan of glass:

dialogues.speaker: T.R. VELIE, JR. UNDERTAKER AND VETERINARY
dialogues.text: And in the lower right hand corner:

dialogues.speaker: ASSAYER NOTARY PUBLIC
dialogues.text: A few of the peeled gold and black letters are completely missing. The building is separated from the structure next to it b an alleyway. Filling the narrow passage is Hector David, long massive body wedged against the wall like an unkempt monument. His little pig eyes meet Macreedy's. Hector spi in the dust with bland insolence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: walks up the steps and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark and shadowy. At the far end of a hallway an insipid  light bulb burns. Macreedy goes toward it, entering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: devoted to the care and preservation of the Dear Departed In the center of the room is a long rectangular slab stai with the juices of those unfortunates who have had occasi to rest thereon. The walls are lined with rickety bookcas jammed, not with volumes, but with the jugs and jars, the chemicals and unguents of Doc's multiple callings. In a c three or four neat pine boxes are stacked one on the othe Doc sits at a cluttered desk feeding a large bowl of gold and sipping a glass of milk. He looks up as Macreedy ente

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Pull up a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Can I use your phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help yourself. (chuckles) You know, you're one of the few people  who's ever been back here I can say  that to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy reaches for the phone book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pausing) What's 4-2-4?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I've got you pegged -- and I think  I have -- you're calling the State  Police. But if I was you -- and I'm  purely glad I'm not -- I'd look it  up myself. (emphatically) I wouldn't trust anybody around here,  including me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy thinks it over and comes to a swift decision. He checks the phone book. Then, picking up phone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Doc) Thanks. (into receiver) 4-2-4.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a cubbyhole behind the hotel clerk's desk in the lobby. A the switchboard is Pete, and above him tacked on the wall the sign:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) 4-2-4...? (he looks up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK revealing Smith standing beside him. Th two men exchange a nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Lines 're busy. (he clicks off the  instrument)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy slowly puts down the phone. Doc sips his milk, a the while staring queasily over the glass at Macreedy. He puts it down, his gaze still fixed on the stranger...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sing-song) I know -- don't tell me -- lines all  busy. They'll be busy all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat,  grimacing) Don't look at me like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I'm a potential customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody is -- and I get 'em coming  and going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to a topographic map hanging on the wall -- a lar impressive map -- faded, fly-blown and divided into secti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing toward it) First I sell 'em a piece of land.  Think they farm it? Nope. They dig  for gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves to photograph beside the map on the wall -- a la impressive photograph of a placer mine in operation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rip off the top soil of ten  winding hills. They sprint in here,  fog-heaved with excitement, lugging  nuggets, big and bright and shiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves to his desk, picks up a glistening blob of stone resting next to an assayer's scales, and examines it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rhetorically) Is it gold?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bangs the rock down next to the scales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not! Do they quit? They do  not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves to a third illustration -- a colored reproductio large and impressive -- of acres upon green acres of prod in bloom; the kind of picture Southern Pacific places abo its calendars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with theatrical  gesture toward  reproduction) Then they decide to farm. Farm! In  country so dry you have to prime a  man before he can spit, and before  you can say "Fat Sam" they're stalled,  stranded and starving. They get weevil- brained and buttsprung...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves to the coffins piled in a corner and runs his ha down the smooth pine sides with loving tenderness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) So I bury 'em. (a beat, as he rejoins  Macreedy in the center  of the room) But why should I bore you with my  triumphs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I've got a problem of my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc nods; he points vaguely toward the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like an old testament  prophet) They're going to kill you with no  hard feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nastily) And you'll just sit on your hands  and let them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get waspish with me, young  feller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel for you, but I'm consumed  with apathy. Why should I mix in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To save a life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got enough trouble saving my own. (he refills his glass  from a milk bottle  on the desk) I try to live right and drink my  orange juice every day. But mostly I  try to mind my own business. Which  is something I'd advise you to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a little late for that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can still get out of town. And  you'd better get out like a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a key ring  from his pocket) I got sort of a limousine at your  disposal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tossing him the key) Out back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy snares the key and walks out. Doc gets up to fol him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old-fashioned hearse, with plate glass sides and elabo lead candelabra -- Doc's "limousine" -- is parked a few s from the door. Macreedy climbs in behind the wheel as Doc comes out and stands on the small back porch. Macreedy turns on the ignition switch. His foot kicks ove the starter, but the spark doesn't catch. He tries again, then again. He pauses, frowns, as Doc comes down from the porch and joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concentrating on the  dashboard) Won't start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously, to Macreedy) Something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just won't start...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again he presses the ignition switch. Nothing. And sudden in b.g., the great bulk of Hector David looms up, leaning against the porch pillar at the corner of the alleyway. H expression is almost dreamy. For a moment he stands there while Macreedy toys with the ignition and the sick engine wheezes and grinds. Then he ambles up to the hearse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gratuitously) Could be the wirin'. Why don't you  look under the hood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For that I thank you. (pause) How much time you think I've got  before...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll wait at least till dark. (angrily) They'd be afraid to see each other's  faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slapping Doc's  shoulder lightly) Well, so long, Doc. I can't say it's  been charming but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. But I'm going on foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's no good. You stray ten yards  off Main Street, and you'll be stone,  cold dead. (offers Macreedy a  cigarette) That's the situation, in a nut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy takes the cigarette, lighting a match with one h He puts the fire to Doc's smoke and then lights his own. inhales, exhales, thinking. Finally... Macreedy gets out of the car. Hector has already opened t hood. Doc peers nervously over his shoulder. As they stud the engine, Hector's horsey face appears behind them. He  gestures toward the engine.

dialogues.speaker: THE ENGINE
dialogues.text: Focal point: a hopeless snarl of ignition wires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the wirin', like I said. Now  wasn't that a good guess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly he takes off his wrist watch and puts it in his pa pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) It can be fixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignoring Hector, he bends over the engine, controlling hi obvious awareness that Hector has fouled up the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy. Unless, of course, this here  wire... (reaching inside the  hood, pointing) ...got broke or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly, heatedly,  turning on Hector) Do the nice little things, like keep  your big fat nose out of my business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector's eyes go hard. He reaches out suddenly, one great hand closing over the distributor cap. He yanks, ripping feed wires out of their sockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (triumphantly, holding  up the wires) Yep. It's the wirin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still gripping the wires, he walks off. Doc simmers down. turns to face Macreedy, who hasn't moved. Now Macreedy sl lowers the hood of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, after a beat) I'm sorry, son. You got to admit, I  tried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if to himself) Maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I can't get out of town, maybe I  can get the state cops in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably) You tried the phone, didn't you? You  know what happened, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another way. I'll be seeing  you, Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off. Doc looks after him grimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) I hope you'll be seeing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy stands at the high counter, writing on a Postal  Telegraph blank. Behind the counter, watching him nervous is Hastings. At the agent's elbow is a big pitcher with d on the glass. It holds a pale liquid and a chunk of ice. eyes on Macreedy, Hastings refills a glass tumbler. He ta a gulp as Macreedy puts down the pencil and pushes the me toward him. Now Hastings puts down his glass, picks up th form and scans it hurriedly. He looks at Macreedy, eyes g with anxiety...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You notifyin' the state po-lice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting a bill on  the counter) That's what it says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hastings again refills his glass, slopping the liquid ove on the counter. He picks up the glass, hesitates, offers awkwardly to Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (plaintively) Lemonade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy shakes his head. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mopping his forehead) It's hot as Billy-be-durned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drinks, puts down the glass. Macreedy pushes the bill  across the counter toward him. Hastings picks it up ginge then pauses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you like lemonade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought much about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It don't have the muzzle velocity of  some other drinks drunk around here,  but it's good for what ails you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) What ails you, Mr. Hastings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you so upset about... (points) ...this wire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you afraid, Mr. Hastings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me...? (a beat, then softly) I guess I am. (awkwardly he puts  Macreedy's bill back  on the counter) But what's the use talkin'...? (with grudging respect) You don't know what it's like, being  scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not unsympathetically) You want me to describe the symptoms?  Right this minute I'm scared half to  death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) You should be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But not of the state police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stonily) Neither am I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what are you afraid of? The  grave at Adobe Flat? A grave nobody  marked, nobody knows anything about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That ain't it, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it Smith? (no answer) Is it?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squirming) Look, Mr. Macreedy. I'm just a good  neighbor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Smith you are. How about to Komako?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meeting Macreedy's  eyes) I never seen Komako in my life.  Honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again pushes the  bill toward Hastings) Then send that wire, and bring me  the answer. You'll do that, won't  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pauses, then worriedly  picking up the bill) Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy turns and walks out. Hastings stands sweating,  staring hard at the message in his hand as...

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script. INT. SAM'S BAR & GRILL A few loafers are at the bar, draped bonelessly on high  stools. There is the usual array of bottles and glasses  aligned before a cracked, discolored mirror. In the corne is a jukebox. Along the opposite wall is a line of low st facing a counter covered with oil-cloth thumb-tacked in p Behind it is a greasy hot plate and a couple of soiled  displays -- breakfast food, soft drinks, etc. At the gril counter is Sam, cleaning his finger-nails with a toothpic At the bar, engaged in a worrisome conversation, are four loafers, FRANKLIN KROOL, WALT MURTRY, RON BENTHAM and STE LENARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, I won't have anything to  do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding emphatically) Live and let live, that's what I  say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning) I don't know. I just don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bentham) You gonna brood about it? Or you  want another beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beer, I guess. Only...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up, and something makes him hesitate... WHAT HE SEES -- EXT. BAR & GRILL - MACREEDY  stopping in front of the restaurant. On the window large, rough capital letters in water paint proclaim: SAM'S SANITARY BAR & GRILL Macreedy pauses, shrugs and then enters. INT. BAR & GRILL Sam is still working on his finger nails. He evidences li interest in the stranger, but at the bar in b.g. the loaf stiffen. Macreedy takes a stool in front of Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chili wit' beans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chili wit'out beans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like the taste, that's  what they make ketchup for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case, I'll have it. And a  cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door of the Bar & Grill opens. Smith and Coley en They walk to Macreedy, stopping just a few feet behind hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Macreedy, with  menacing friendliness) You still around? I thought you didn't  like this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleasantly) Going to, or coming from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staying put.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns again as Sam plops an unseasonable mess of chili front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Smith, gesturing  a thumb toward  Macreedy) No comment, he says. No comment, and  all the time he's got my chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy smiles tiredly. He half turns toward Coley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always seem to be taking somebody's  place around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up, with his chili, and sits down three stools aw Coley straddles the stool Macreedy has vacated. He squirm on it, his movements exaggerated. Now he spins to face Sm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This seat ain't comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was afraid of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'd like the seat you're on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Macreedy, mildly) He's as changeable as a prairie fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Coley) Suppose you tell me where to sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coley opens his mouth but, realizing he has been  outmaneuvered, closes it again. The loafers in b.g. are  silent, watching. Sam, seemingly oblivious to Coley's pre on Macreedy, places a bottle of ketchup in front of the  stranger. Coley gets up slowly and walks stiff-legged to  Macreedy. He takes the bottle of ketchup and, without rem the cap, upends it over Macreedy's plate. The cap is drow in a deluge of ketchup which overflows the plate and runs onto the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Macreedy) I hope that ain't too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Smith, gesturing  toward Coley) Your friend's a very [...] fellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Sort of unpredictable, too. Got a  temper like a rattlesnake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me all over. I'm half hoss,  half alligator. Mess with me, I'll  kick a lung outta you. What do you  think of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talking to you is like pulling teeth.  You wear me out. (loudly, after a beat) You're a yellow-bellied Jap lover.  Am I right or wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not only wrong -- you're wrong  at the top of your voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like my voice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again turning to  Smith) I think your friend's trying to start  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now why-ever would he want to do  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe he figures, needle  me enough and I'll crack. Maybe I'll  even fight back. Then he or Hector --  your other ape -- would beat me to  death and cop a plea of self-defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think that'll be necessary.  You're so scared now you'll probably  drown in your own sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before that happens, couldn't I pick  a fight with you if I tied one hand  behind me...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy rises to go out. As he passes Coley, Coley takes his limp left arm and spins him slowly but firmly around. The two men face each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I tied both hands...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy shakes free of Coley's grasp. Coley lunges. His right fist streaks toward Macreedy's face. Macreedy ducks weaving with the punch. He grabs Coley's belt, twisting  Coley's body. The momentum of the swing throws Coley off  balance. As he goes past Macreedy, the stranger tugs at h belt, twisting him to one side. He plants his left foot f on the toes of Coley's left boot, for a split second anch Coley in place. He chops the under side of his open hand a short, vicious arc that lands solidly under Coley's ear With the same motion, he brings the heel of his hand hard against and slightly under the tip of Coley's nose. The  cartilage shatters. Blood spills down his face. Following through, Macreedy's elbow smashes beneath Coley's cheekbo Macreedy's arm goes past the astonished, wind-burned face finding Coley's right wrist. He jerks the wrist out and  backward. It snaps. Coley whimpers, his face twisted in p and perplexity. His body lolls forward. Macreedy steps ba He raises his right shoulder a few inches. His bent right arm drives up like a piston attached to the shoulder's li Fist and arm seem all one rigid piece with only the limbe shoulder giving them motion. The fist strikes Coley's fac covering for a moment one side of his chin and a corner o his mouth between cheekbone and jawbone. Coley shuts his  eyes and falls unconscious. Smith, a puzzled expression on his face, watches Coley fa He takes half a step toward him. Macreedy looks at Smith. Smith stops. Macreedy's face is wooden, with a trace of  sullenness around the hard lines of his mouth. Working  methodically, Macreedy frisks Coley. He takes from a pock a long, ugly knife. He snaps the spring and the four-inch blade leaps into place. He looks at the knife in his hand and then at Smith. He smiles gently, even dreamily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Smith) Wouldn't it be easier if you just  waited till I turned my back? (looking toward the  loafers at the bar,  then back at Smith) Or are there too many witnesses  present?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy walks slowly toward him, holding the knife. The only three feet apart. Smith's hand goes to a pocket, clo inside over the outline of a pistol. Sam glances from Mac to Smith to the unconscious Coley. He sidles toward the d and runs out fast. (NOTE: From this point to end of scene INTERCUT from Macreedy and Smith to exploit the reactions the loafers at the bar.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with effortless  ferocity) You're still in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So are you. (Smith snorts) Whatever happens -- you're lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got things a bit twisted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You killed Komako. Sooner or later  you'll go up for it. Not because you  killed him -- in this town you  probably could have gotten away with  it -- but because you didn't even  have the guts to do it alone. You  put your trust in guys like him... (gesturing toward the  unconscious Coley) ...and Hector -- they're not the  most dependable of God's creatures.  Sooner or later they'll get the idea  you're playing them for saps. What'll  you do then -- peel them off, one by  one? And in the meantime if any one  of them breaks, you'll go down hard.  Because they got something on you.  Something to use when things get  tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a quick motion, he tosses the knife to Smith. Smith  catches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they're getting tougher every  minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks past Smith and goes out the door. Self-conscious holding the knife, Smith turns to face the loafers at the bar. They say nothing; they stare at him, through him, li a panel of ghouls. The door opens, admitting Sam and Doc, who carries his little black medical bag. Doc looks at Co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, full of awe) Man... man-oh-man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes to Coley, bending down over him. Smith has remain motionless as a monument. Now he doubles shut the knife i his hand. He pockets it, and without even glancing at Col turns quickly and goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc sits deep in the battered upholstery of one of the ch He stares fiercely across the room at Smith who is on the couch, reading a neatly folded newspaper. Behind him at t clerk's desk, Pete is fitfully involved in a game of  solitaire. At the foot of the stairs Hector is pouring ch into a slot machine. It whines, grinds, and clicks with  rhythmic monotony, but it never seems to pay off. In the  chair nearest Doc is Tim, with one of his boots off. He w hard and with some concentration, removing the other. The he places them neatly at the foot of his chair. He wiggle his toes -- watching them with some interest. The wheeze and whir of the slot machine stops. The sudden silence turns the eyes of the men toward Hector and the o arm bandit. They follow his gaze up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRWAY
dialogues.text: walks down, carrying his suitcase. He goes to Pete at the clerk's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any message -- a telegram?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returning to his  cards) Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Macreedy turns from the desk, Doc joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Macreedy, shrilly,  gruffly) In case you're interested, Coley'll  live. (glaring at Smith and  Hector) I'm truly sorry to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith coolly continues to read his paper. It is Hector wh turns toward Doc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Doc, jerking a  fat hand toward  Macreedy) Your friend's pretty tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's wicked. He defends himself  when he's attacked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy ignores the exchange of words. He walks across t frayed carpet to the nearest chair and drops into it. Doc who has followed him, stands looking down at Macreedy for long moment. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with some irritation) Well...? You going to just sit here  and let time run out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for a wire. From the  state cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sent it through Hastings? (an audible sigh) Just don't expect an answer, if that's  the way you sent it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking toward the  door) No? (he rises)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc follows his gaze as Hastings enters the lobby and loo around. He sees Macreedy coming toward him. He walks rigi in an arc past Macreedy to Smith. He holds out a Postal  Telegraph form. Smith puts down his paper and takes it.  Macreedy, followed by Doc, goes over to Smith. Tim in his stockinged feet joins them. Smith scans the message. He looks up to meet Macreedy's g Smith rises. Hector swaggers over from the slot machine.  Hastings slips around the back of the couch, protected by the barricade of Hector's great body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evenly, to Smith) I think that's for me. (he takes the message  from Smith's hand  and quickly glances  at it. Looking up at  Hastings) Where's the answer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hastings is silent. A brittle expression of bemusement cr Smith's features.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You expect an answer -- to a wire  that's never sent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy's mouth compresses in a harsh grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just a thought -- (his eyes turn to  Hastings. Hastings  wilts) -- a thought dazzling in its purity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy takes a step toward Hastings. The telegraph agen bounces away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) You're in a jam, Hastings. You gave  my telegram to Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) You warty wretch! That's a federal  offense!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Smith) You're in deep, too. (grins hard) Like I said, it's getting tougher  and tougher. (to Tim) Sheriff, you'd better do something  about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim hesitates, blinking his eyes worriedly, shifting from one stockinged foot to the other. Smith watches him insol as he takes the message from Macreedy and gestures with i vaguely...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Smith) I reckon that's right, Mr. Smith...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a jerk, Tim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Smith, seriously) Divulging information -- there's a  law...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim, you're pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doggedly) Could be. But I'm still Sheriff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the point. You're not Sheriff  any more. You just lost a job, you're  so pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches out, clawing the badge from Tim's chest. He ja it on Hector's vest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hector) All right, Sheriff. Take over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't I? I put him in office. Now I  take him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector moves his elephantine bulk within inches of Macree

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. You want to register a complaint?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy doesn't answer. Hector takes the message from Ti limp hand and tears it into little pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To register a complaint, boy, you've  got to have evidence. You got  evidence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a big mouth, boy, makin'  accusations, disturbin' the peace.  There's laws in this county protectin'  innocent folks from big mouths. Why,  I'd just hate to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Hector... (wearily) Come on, Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks out, the new Sheriff strutting beside him, with  Hastings in their wake. For a moment Macreedy, Doc and Ti stand in the center of the lobby. Pete eyes them non- committally and goes back to his solitaire. He glances up now and then, moving the cards with a purposeful sort of  slowness, as of a more natural swiftness restrained by hi preoccupation with the three men in the lobby. Macreedy is deep in thought. Abstractedly he tugs at his  collar and then repeats the ritual of lighting a cigarett Tim's shoulders are slumped. Humiliation has corroded him flesh and soul. Even Doc is momentarily subdued; he too,  feels degraded, unclean. Macreedy looks from one to the o of the good, ineffectual companions that circumstance has haphazardly tossed his way. He takes a few steps to his  suitcase, Doc and Tim trailing him; Doc, for want of some better to do; Tim, out of his deep, inexpressible need fo support. Macreedy takes an untapped bottle of whiskey fro his bag. He thumbs the cork loose and holds the bottle ou to Tim. Tim takes a drink. The light on the clerk's desk goes on, and we are aware t day has gone and that night is falling. The pressing, fie light has drained from the lobby, leaving a shadowy, silv dreariness. The shadows have lengthened and the silver ha tarnished with the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hopefully) It's all right, Tim. We're not licked  yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (numbly) Ain't we? I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There comes a time, Tim, when a man's  just got to do something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me. I'm useless, and I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imploring) No man is useless, if he's got a  friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete comes out from behind the desk, walking from one lam in the lobby to another, turning them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your friend, Tim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Doc the whiskey bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jabbing at Macreedy  with a thumb) He's going to need you before the  night is over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He downs a snort, then looks at Pete, who approaches them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) And all the useful men are on the  other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Pete turns on the lamp behind Doc, he reacts ever so  slightly to Doc's words. His almost imperceptible grimace not lost on Macreedy. Macreedy watches the young man as h continues to light the lamps...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Lemme alone, I tell ya!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc slams the whiskey bottle down on a nearby table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't let you alone! I can't let  myself alone! Don't you understand  that? (he turns from Tim to  Pete, who is unable  to shake his gaze.  Then, sadly, fiercely) Four years ago something terrible  happened here. We did nothing about  it. Nothing. The whole town fell  into a sort of settled melancholy,  and the people in it closed their  eyes and held their tongues and failed  the test with a whimper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Self-consciously Pete has backed off until now he leans  against the outside of the clerk's desk. But he still can shut his ears to what Doc is saying...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now something terrible is going to  happen again, and in a way we're  lucky because we've been given a  second chance. And this time I won't  close my eyes, I won't hold my tongue,  and if I'm needed I won't fail. (almost harshly, again  facing Tim) And neither will you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim sighs, running a thick hand over his forehead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got such a headache, I'm bewildered.  I hurt all over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know -- (unconsciously his  right arm strays to  massage the paralyzed  left) -- pain is bewildering. I came here  bewildered, full of self-pity, afraid  to fight back. (gesturing with his  hand to Pete) And then your friend Smith tried to  kill me. (the muscles around  Pete's mouth tighten) Funny, how a man clings to the earth  when he feels there's a chance he  may never see it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a difference between clinging  to the earth... (eyeing Tim almost  contemptuously) ...and crawling on it. You going to  stand by and watch forever?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) I ain't gonna watch, and I ain't  gonna get into it, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a moment of crashing silence. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gettin' out. I'm sorry, Mr.  Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly he lumbers out of the lobby. Doc watches him go. A the benumbing silence, cut finally, unexpectedly by...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Doc) You'd be smart to get out, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily turning to  Pete) There's too many smart guys around  here. I'm glad I'm a dummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a troublesome dummy. You're  liable to end up on your own slab...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heatedly) I expect to be in a lot more trouble  before I die...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home, Doc. (he jerks his head  toward Macreedy, and  with mock bravado...) He's all washed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning harshly at  him) You think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His right hand closes over the neck of the whiskey bottle the end table. Abstractedly fingering it, he walks with t deliberate steps toward Pete at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was washed up when I got off that  train...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues to advance inexorably toward Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) You shouldn' of got off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had to. I had one last duty to perform  before I resigned from the human  race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quizzically) I thought you were going to Los  Angeles, that hot-bed of pomp and  vanity. Is that resigning from the  human race?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugging) L.A.'s a good jumping off place --  for the Islands, for Mexico, Central  America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (again shrugs) I don't know. I was looking for a  place to get lost, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slapping his paralyzed  arm with the whisky  bottle) Because of this. I thought I'd never  be able to function again. (turning to Pete) Thanks to your friend Smith, I found  I was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is now within a couple of yards of Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) Sure. You're a man of action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) I know your problem. (with mounting vigor) You'd like me to die quickly, without  wasting too much of your time... (Pete opens his mouth  to say something,  but Macreedy presses  on) ...or silently, without making you  feel too uncomfortable... or  thankfully, without making your  memories of the occasion too  unpleasant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment Pete stares at Macreedy, terribly disturbed the incisiveness of Macreedy's analysis. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) My memories are so pleasant as it  is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In sudden frustration, Pete grabs the deck of cards on th clerk's desk and slams them down hard. They scatter. He t stares blankly [...] between Doc and Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly pressing his  advantage) What happened, Pete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to tell him -- or you  want me to? (beat) Smith owns Adobe Flat. He leased it  to Komako -- thought he had cheated  him, thought Komako could never even  run stock without water. There was  never any water on Adobe Flat. Komako  dug a well, by hand. He must have  went down one hundred and fifty feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got water, plenty. Smith was pretty  sore. He didn't like Japs anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an understatement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day after Pearl Harbor, Smith  went to Sand City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I know. To enlist. He was turned  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was sore when he got back. About  ten o'clock he started drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten o'clock in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hector joined him, and Coley.  Then Sam, and about nine p.m. -- me.  We were all drunk -- patriotic drunk.  We went out to Komako's for a little  fun, I guess -- scare him a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd seen him around some, but none  of us knew him. When he heard us  coming, he locked the door. Smith  started a fire. The Jap came running  out. His clothes were burning. Smith  shot him. I didn't even know Smith  had a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you all got scared, buried him,  kept quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete nods helplessly, bowing his head. Macreedy sighs, lo down at the bottle in his hand, slowly puts it on the tab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Did Komako have any family besides  his son Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) His son...? Nobody around here knew  he had a son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had one. But he's dead, too. He's  buried in Italy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, Mr. Macreedy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Komako died in Italy, saving my  life. They gave him a medal. I came  here to give it to his father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Doc, realizing the enormity of Macreedy's admiss frowns, rubs a hand across his tired eyes. Pete looks at  Macreedy for a long, shocked moment. He shivers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awfully) God forgive me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the bottle from the table and shakily pours a sh glass of liquor. As he raises it to his mouth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Pete, harshly  guttural) It'll take a lot of whiskey to wash  out your guts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is motionless, holding the glass inches from his lip hypnotized by Macreedy's voice, as hard and as cold as hi eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And it will never help -- not  even a barrel full washes away murder!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy's hand shoots out, in a short, inexorable arc,  smashing his palm across the shot glass. The whiskey burs in a spray, the glass flies halfway across the room,  shattering as it lands against something solid. Pete is  stunned, Doc perplexed, at Macreedy's violence. They star at him... Macreedy's eyes are murky. The creases between the brows  over his nose are deep. His nostrils move in and out with his breathing. Pete and Doc regard him with growing  uneasiness. Rage comes into Macreedy's face, turning it a painful red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But maybe I'm wrong. Go on -- drink. (scornfully) What else is left for you?! (mounting anger) You're as dead as Komako, only you  don't know it! (roaring) You also don't know that it's not  enough to feel guilty. It's not enough  to confess. It's not enough to say,  "Forgive me, I've done wrong."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Macreedy. Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning on him) Sit down?! Or would you rather have  me kneel, to beg his pardon for  raising a touchy subject?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete squirms under Macreedy's relentless attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) You don't have to remind me. I've  never forgotten...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's mighty noble of you.  You feel ashamed -- that's noble,  too. (in mounting crescendo) And four years from now you'll  probably be sitting here telling  somebody else you haven't forgotten  me. That's progress -- you'll still  be ashamed but I'll be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy grabs the bottle, shoving it across the table to Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, have your drink. (with exorbitant scorn) You need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete pushes the bottle aside, too ravaged by Macreedy's w and his own thoughts to drink. He shakes his head grimly then, with sudden decision, goes to the switchboard and p in a line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning over counter,  staring at him) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone, ignoring  Doc) Hello, Liz. Now listen... I... 'm  getting Macreedy out of town...

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY AND DOC
dialogues.text: as they exchange a glance. Doc takes a long, deep breath relief. Macreedy frowns thoughtfully. He strains to liste to Liz, but all he (and we) can hear is the staccato jumb of her words over the wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he cuts Liz short...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) I don't care about Smith! Let him  try to kill me -- I might as well be  dead as...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again Liz's voice incoherent over the phone, and again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone,  interrupting) Liz, Liz... There's not much of me  left any more, but however little it  is I won't waste it! (again Liz's voice  briefly; then...) I'm telling you because we need your  help. (again Liz's voice) ...No matter about the past -- you've  got to do this! You'd be saving two  lives, Liz. Macreedy's, and mine. (again Liz answers  and...) All right. Yeah... I've told him  everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly he replaces the phone on the switch-board. He come around from behind the desk, joining Macreedy and Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) She'll be here in five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Pete. Thanks very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Doc are nervously alert, drained of energy, wait Hector is downright bored. He toys with his pistol, squin at it, twirling the barrel. Finding neither interest nor  pleasure in the piece, he jams it back in his holster and strolls with exaggerated surety out on the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The congregation of loafers look up as Hector emerges. Im with his own bullying importance, he draws the pistol,  maneuvers an extravagant pinwheel and a few other gaudy  tricks. Then he sighs as boredom again takes over. He wal down the steps to catch a bit of air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The disappearance of Hector (o.s.) down the street galvan them into action. They hurry out of the lobby toward the  back of the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vague in the pallid light escaping through a few back win The hotel's rear door is tightly shut. Around the far cor of the street (extreme b.g.) comes the gangling body of H David. He walks toward CAMERA. Perhaps twenty-five yards  away he stops to rest against a fence like a leaning towe

dialogues.speaker: HECTOR
dialogues.text: His hand goes to a pocket and comes out with a crumpled h pack of cigarettes. Suddenly the movement is arrested;  something at the other end of the street captures his ble attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jeep, headlights off, slowly turns the corner, pulls up the curb and parks.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: pockets his cigarettes and starts slowly for the jeep, a  quizzical frown on his horsy face. He approaches the back door of the hotel, oblivious to it as he continues toward the jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the far end b.g., toward the lobby, a single unshaded  light bulb burns dully. A slight figure stands in f.g. To one side is a narrow U-shaped alcove blanketed in heavy  shadows. The features of the man in the hall and the slim lines of his body blend vaguely in the darkness. With eno care, he turns a knob and opens the door leading to the a behind the hotel. Light thrown by the back windows reveal that the figure is Pete. The same pallid light from the a glancing across the alcove, momentarily illuminates it. G as close to the recessed wall as is humanly possible is D He is partially shielded by one of those hotel hose wheel around which an old fire hose is wound. The heavy brass n of the hose hangs from the end. Doc grips a twelve-inch length of lead pipe. Pete swallow nervously and peers outside, first to the right, then to left. His eyes glaze with fear, and his jaw tightens with tension.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING PETE
dialogues.text: as he stares at Hector walking toward the jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (controlling his  jangled nerves) Hector!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hector stops, turns to face Pete. He hesitates, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmmm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, with a final glance at the jeep, Hector lumbers to  Pete, who disappears inside the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Hector enters and stops. Pete quickly closes the door  behind him and walks toward the lobby, attempting to draw Hector toward the black alcove center screen b.g. But Hec is not to be sucked in. He glares at Pete, waiting. (NOTE The following dialogue is delivered sotto voce.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's still in his room. Macreedy, I  mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So...? You want me to tuck him in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you wanted to tell  Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explaining something  he feels Pete already  knows) Smith said he'd be here at midnight.  He don't want to be disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jams a cigarette in his mouth. Pete watches him franti as he searches his pockets for a match. He can't find one

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a match?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. I got some in the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to turn. Hector's pig eyes are slits of suspici Before Pete can move, Hector reaches out, hooking two hea fingers inside a pocket of Pete's shirt. Slowly Hector's  expression changes to one of insidious cunning. His finge come out of Pete's pocket, and between them is a paper bo of matches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you didn't have a match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is unable to answer. He is scared to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sweating with frustration. Hector is six feet away, and a too far away for Doc to risk an attack with his lead pipe Doc looks around vaguely, wildly, for another weapon. A  fraction of an inch from his nose is the hose wheel. For split second he hesitates. Then slowly, with infinite car he tightens the heavy brass nozzle and begins to unwind t hose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Hector is alert. He studies Pete's twitching face.  Elaborately he tears a match from the pack and scratches It takes fire, cupped in the rampart of his big hands. It lights up the hall, and as Hector looks around he sees  something through a mirror -- over his shoulder and six f away Doc materializes out of the shadows of the alcove. A Hector whirls, going for his gun, Doc swings the hose wit sudden deadly aim. It uncoils like a snake, and the brass nozzle crashes with a mighty thud across Hector's skull.  Hector groans. He sinks unconscious to the floor. Doc sta there, paralyzed by his action. Pete tears toward the lob

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Pete rushes in. He moves directly to the desk, leans o and presses the buzzer behind the desk three times. He tu and runs back toward the rear of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Macreedy barrels down. He pauses briefly in the hall a he sees Doc still standing with the hose and the nozzle  dangling like a pendulum from his hand. Their eyes lock  briefly in understanding...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a half smile) I'll never forgive you, Doc... (he gestures toward  Hector, out cold) ...for depriving me of that pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heads toward the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Macreedy rushes out. He pauses, looking quickly right, then left. He sees a jeep parked at the curb far down the street. He runs toward it. The jeep, its headlights off,  starts for him. He swings onto the moving vehicle, fallin heavily into the seat beside Liz Brooks. He slumps there, breathing heavily as the jeep, with a grinding of gears,  cuts through the night, picking up speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Pete joins Doc. Silently, motionlessly, the two men st for a long moment at Hector -- particularly at the pistol lying beside him. Then they look at each other, and the s thought seems to flash in their minds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they speed down the long empty ribbon of road. Liz dri hard. Macreedy turns in the bucket seat, looking back tow Black Rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I can't get more out of this  heap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a burst of  irritation) We could make better time with a dog  team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) You're doing the best you can. (a beat) Aren't you, Liz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't expect too much from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dryly) Don't worry, I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) I mean, people have always expected  things from me. You know why? Because  I'm pretty. Well, that's not enough.

dialogues.speaker: JEEP
dialogues.text: with Liz and Macreedy as she cuts sharply into a crossroa She drives skillfully over the knotty road which is littl more than a trail. Her lovely features are distorted with her discontent and the ache for attention. After a moment she gives voice to her fantasy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Maybe I could have been something --  a model, or something. (glancing at him) You don't believe that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't, really. I'm a dime a  dozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I don't believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too little and too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's never too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lack the muscle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning) Why is muscle so important?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cynically) Oh, you're the brainy type. (harshly) Did it take brains to rough up Coley?  Whatever you did to Hector, you didn't  do it with brains. How'd you get  Pete to change his mind?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not with muscle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And not with brains, either. He's a  pushover for a muscle man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm beginning' to think it runs in  the family. (looking at her hard) You think strength is in the width  of a man's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does not catch the glance she darts him; his extreme  awareness is anchored not to the girl at his side but to terrain ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd sure have liked to see you tangle  with Reno Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't around when I left... Maybe  I will yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes strain to sweep the country -- each boulder, eac outcropping, each stunted tree. But substance and shadow blurred and fuzzy in the dark night, black on black.

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: JEEP
dialogues.text: with Macreedy and Liz as it winds to the far end of the  boulders on a trail that drops off into a flat basin. Sol forms loom up in the darkness; they are unrecognizable, y Macreedy senses some tense familiarity with the terrain.. He frowns. Suddenly Liz brakes the jeep -- so sharply Mac lurches forward in the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alert, expectant) What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vamping nervously) We need water... (she turns off engine,  pulling ignition key  from its lock) ...radiator's overheating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves away from Macreedy to get out of the jeep. He  reaches across quickly, gripping her arm. She turns to fa him, disturbed by his hardness of jaw and eye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leggo! Leggo of me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly they are hit by a blinding pair of headlights li [...] The beams cut jaggedly through the night, throwing  into sharp immediate relief the lava rocks, the broken  windmill, the gutted house, the litter-strewn, unmarked g at Adobe Flat. Liz throws away the ignition key. Macreedy bails out of t jeep, still holding the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they fall to the earth. Macreedy pins her down. Then i quick succession, four emphatically loud SHOTS from a rif squirt into the shale around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly, through his  teeth) You're stupid, Liz. You're a fool.  If he finishes me, he's got to finish  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up blindly into the headlights glaring from the  granitic high ground some 60 yards away. His grip on the  girl's shoulder is like a steel trap. He pushes her down  beside Komako's grave, hugging the side of the jeep as a  SHOT rips the gravel at their feet. Pulling the girl with him, he takes cover in the slight concavity of the grave. The jeep is between them and the headlights -- between th and the source of the gunfire. Liz struggles to break awa Suddenly bullets kick up a storm around him. A bullet sma into the flowers, exploding tiny cruel fragments of dirt  into Macreedy's face. He gasps in pain, releasing Liz. He rubs his eyes as if to convince himself that he is not bl Liz breaks from the grave. Now, five yards from Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling toward the  headlights) Smitty! Smitty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) I'm here, honey. Just head for the  car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz half turns, facing Macreedy with a vicious smile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an almost bantering  voice) So long, Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts toward the headlights.

dialogues.speaker: GO WITH LIZ
dialogues.text: She reaches the foot of the rocky ridge, with the two eno eyes on top. She begins to climb, up... up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Just a few more steps, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is almost at the top; a vertically sheer rock about f feet high separates her from it. She looks up at Smith,  towering over her at the edge of the precipice. He holds rifle almost languorously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathlessly) Get him! Get him now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easily) First things first, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl is frightened by the menace in Smith's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unsure, reaching out  her hand) Help me up, Smitty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were going to help me, Liz. (she looks at him  quizzically) I still need your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) I did what you said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two started out in a car. That's  the way you'll end up. Over a cliff,  burning. (she tries to interrupt  him, but he goes  on...) You can blame that on Macreedy, too.  He said I had too many witnesses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dry whisper) But why me? Why start with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to start with somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He brings the rifle down, aiming almost casually at Liz. eyes go wide. She steps back, spins around, running crazi down the steep incline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling wildly) Macreedy! Macreedy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHOT rings out. She falls forward, rolling slowly down embankment. She lies there. Blood trickles from the corne of her pretty mouth. A rattling noise rises from deep in throat, and then subsides. In the silence the outline of Reno Smith emerges. Holding his rifle at the ready, his silhouette illuminated sharpl in the twin beams of light, he climbs down the side of th cliff. He looks toward the jeep and Macreedy, not once at the girl at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly, almost  reproachfully) You shouldn't have done that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith pays no attention to her. He advances inexorably wi rifle held at his hip. He fires at Macreedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy wipes the last of the fragments from his eyes. H face is still streaked with dirt and shale. He turns,  searching for something, anything, to fight back with. Th he remembers... Stiffening, his body set, his eyes narrow he moves purposefully toward the front of the jeep and cr under it. Again Smith opens up on him. Bullet after bulle pours into the confined space, nicking the wall, ricochet off the jeep with a frightening, fluttery, wheezing sound The firing stops again and in the silence we HEAR a famil TRICKLE, as in running water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: re-loads his rifle. Stiffly, he starts slowly down over t rocks toward his unarmed victim...

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY
dialogues.text: He has unscrewed the nut and unconnected the gas line wit the carburator. A spurt of gasoline is running out. With quick motion he picks up an empty whisky bottle from the  litter-strewn earth. He fills it with gasoline, quickly s the nut back on. Now he sweeps his necktie free of his co Holding it with his teeth, he tears the felt lining free  from its silk face. He twists half the lining inside the  bottle, knotting the other end securely around the bottle neck, leaving a long strand dangling.

dialogues.speaker: SMITH
dialogues.text: moving rigidly toward the hole. He stops, levels his rifl fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: pinned down in the direct line of fire. The burst of the  rifle stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: not more than twenty-five yards away, advancing carefully rifle at the ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: lights a match, placing the flame to the dangling end of tie. It catches. He flings himself to his feet and with t same motion whips the fiery bottle like a football, hard straight toward Smith. Smith fires once, fast and wild. T bottle crashes against the rocks at his feet and bursts w a shattering explosion. Smith screams as the razor-sharp  slivers rip his flesh. In a puff of flame, his clothes ig He drops the rifle and goes down, squirming frantically o the black ashy ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: favoring Macreedy as he tears out of the hole. He hurls  himself at Smith. Wooden-faced, almost dreamy-eyed, he sh the ashy dirt over Smith's prone chest, putting out the f Smith struggles halfway to his feet. Macreedy grabs his  shoulder, helping him up. Smith looks at Macreedy through eyes bleary with fear and pain and shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through his teeth) Go ahead -- kill me. Now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to kill you now, but you  caused too much pain to die quickly. (a beat) You'll be tried in a court of law.  You'll be convicted by a jury. Then  you'll die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives his right fist against Smith's chin. Smith's he snaps back as far as it can go and then wobbles to rest o his chest. He collapses. Macreedy blows out his breath ha He staggers to Liz. As he bends over her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz's jeep, driven by Macreedy, rolls slowly down the emp main street of the sleeping town. Behind him, under a tar the body of the girl lies lifeless across the seat. On th seat beside him is Smith's rifle, the balance a few inche from Macreedy's elbow. On the right front fender of the j Smith sits precariously, his shirt scorched and ragged. H wears a sullen expression of pained indifference. In b.g., as the jeep passes, isolated lights go on, first Doc's house, then in two or three others. Macreedy is  oblivious to them.

dialogues.speaker: A MAN
dialogues.text: almost completely hidden, looks out grimly from a corner the jail window. Protruding through the bars, swiveling t follow the progress of the jeep down the street, is the l ugly muzzle of a rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Macreedy pulls up to the curb in front of the jail and cuts the ignition. He grabs the rifle, and steps around t Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tonelessly, prodding  Smith off the fender  with his rifle) Hands behind your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith complies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Macreedy marches Smith up the steps. The jail door ope A man emerges, wearing a Mackinaw over his vest and carry a rifle. It is Tim. For a moment Macreedy eyes him in sil His gun finger tightens on the rifle in his hand. Tim's r too, is at the ready...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Am I going to have trouble with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. But I sure thought the situation  was going to be like reversed. I  thought I was going to have trouble... (nodding sharply in  Smith's direction) ...with him. I'll take care of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still hesitating) Just as you took care of his buddies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as I took care of his buddies.  Me, an' Doc, and Pete...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of running feet padding along the dirt road  increases on SOUND TRACK. Macreedy turns slightly, to see Doc huffing toward him. The older man climbs the jail ste and comes to an abrupt halt, his eyes going from one to t other of the two men in the stand-off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Macreedy) It's all right, Macreedy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls Tim's Mackinaw to one side, revealing the silver plated star pinned at the breast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Tim here's got his badge back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy swings his rifle from Tim to Smith. Tim lowers h stepping to one side, allowing Smith, covered by Macreedy to enter the jail. He goes in, Doc following. Pete sits  silently at Tim's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In one of the two cells are Coley and Hector. In the othe Sam and Hastings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) Well. The gang is all here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd take one last whack at  my job. Even if Smith killed me for  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jerking his head  toward Smith) Put him in with Hastings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim turns his key in the cell door. Macreedy tiredly goes Pete at the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sister's outside, Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete rises. Macreedy halts him momentarily, gripping his  arm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) She's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete walks dazedly out the door. Tim grabs Smith's should and propels him roughly through the cell door. He slams i hard. As the clatter of the iron door reverberates harshl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The townspeople, with Doc f.g., are gathered silently in street, staring sadly, dumbly at the hotel before them. D wears a dark business suit, neat and conservative. The do opens (o.s.) and the people look up, their eyes lighting  with expectancy.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE
dialogues.text: Macreedy comes out of the door, carrying his suitcase. Fo moment he pauses, looking at the uplifted faces of the pe in the street. In the distance we HEAR the horn of a stre liner. Macreedy goes down the steps, skirts the watching  crowd and heads for the railroad station. Almost immediat Doc falls in step with him. The townspeople, still silent trail after them

dialogues.speaker: MACREEDY AND DOC
dialogues.text: in f.g., the townspeople behind them. In b.g., as we pass we see the main street just as we saw it when Macreedy en town a few short hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking, after a  beat, to Doc) Tim knows where to find me if I'm  needed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc nods. He blinks and frowns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's on your mind, Doc?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Only... about that medal.  Can we have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "We...?" Can who have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We. (indicating the  townspeople, with a  vague wave of his  hand) Us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we need it, I guess. It's  something we can maybe build on.  This town is wrecked, just as bad as  if it was bombed out. Maybe it can  come back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some towns come back. Some don't. It  depends on the people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A NOISE o.s. attracts Macreedy's attention. He turns, as Doc and the townsmen.

dialogues.speaker: WHAT THEY SEE
dialogues.text: In front of the jail, each of them handcuffed, are Smith, Coley, Hector, Sam and Hastings. Tim and four cops escort them to two State Police cars which are parked beside Tim old sedan and another car (presumably belonging to a memb of the press). The newspaperman (WITHOUT A PRESS CARD IN HAT) stands to one side with Pete. Pete as well as Tim ha changed clothes; they look clean and trim. Coley has his in a sling. Hector's hat hides the bandage on his head.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Macreedy resumes walking toward the abandoned station, wi Doc at his side and the people behind him. The train pull in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still pressing) That medal would help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy is silent. He walks on, to the platform. He paus looking at the people silently in his wake and then at Do He takes a black velvet-covered box from his pocket -- th box containing the medal -- looks at it, and slowly hands to Doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Macreedy. Thanks for  everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy turns and exits from SHOT. The people look after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Macreedy boards the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cars in front of the jail U-turn and start off with t prisoners. The people move silently toward the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy is at the passageway. Slowly the train moves out

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macreedy and a conductor stand at the doorway. The town i seen behind them and the people standing there. In the  distance, Tim's car recedes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curiously) What's the excitement? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shooting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it was something. First time  a streamliner stopped here in four  years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks into the train.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN
dialogues.text: gathering speed, diminishing, far, far into the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: NOTES
dialogues.text: Note from page [9]: (1) The sign should be of whatever ty is feasible and compatible to terrain, emphasizing the  remoteness of Black Rock. It should list three cities wit arrows pointing in the proper directions:
